awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Transformative Innovation for Sustainable HCI through Interventionist Eco-Arts
awd_abstract_narration:
Research in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) on sustainability has recently exploded. The goal of this project is to guide further development of sustainable HCI by informing research in the area with an understanding of contemporary interventionist eco-art practices. By "interventionist eco-art practices" we are referring to a set of artists and projects that combine public and institutional engagement with a commitment to sustainability, to produce artifacts and systems that intervene in environmental issues to raise awareness and provide models for social change. Through such activities, artists push the boundaries of how we use and think about technology and its relationship to the environment. These interventionist eco-art artists and projects suggest new themes and work practices that could usefully inform sustainable HCI. But because they are born from far outside of the traditional sciences, arts-based approaches run into challenges in being taken up and taken seriously as part of HCI. On the one hand, methods and outcomes deriving from the arts are most easily incorporated into HCI by retro-fitting them to existing understandings of HCI as a scientific discipline in ways that blunt their potential to truly add new perspectives. On the other hand, methods and outcomes that remain true to an arts sensibility can suffer marginal status as "artsy HCI" such arts-based approaches are more likely to be considered acceptable for fringework or one-off systems than to be thought of as appropriate or essential for the core research of HCI. In either case, the "edge" of arts-based approaches, that could provide transformative potential for innovation, is dulled.

In this project, groundwork for transdisciplinary engagement between sustainable HCI and interventionist eco-art practices will be laid through an ethnographic case study of interventionist eco-arts practices at the 2010 01 SJ Biennial in San Jose, California to be held September 16 to 19, 2010. The 01SJ Biennial is one of the major international media arts festivals. It attracts tens of thousands of visitors; over 60 artists, designers and collectives are scheduled to participate in the 2010. The theme of 2010 is "Build Your Own World" and the majority of participating projects share a common theme of developing alternative, collaborative and Do-It-Yourself (DIY) approaches social and environmental conditions. As such, it provides a unique opportunity for ethnographic study of a range of projects and practices within a bounded space and timeframe. This research will engage in the following activities (1) observation and analysis of eco-arts projects presented at the 2010 01SJ Biennial; (2) participant-observation in the Biennial as a commissioned art/design collective (3) a project workshop to integrate the results of the first two activities and develop a set of key themes for sustainable HCI (4) follow-on interviews with artists from and the curator of the Biennial.

por.por_cntn:
Environmental sustainability is a hot topic for software designers these days.  While there is an explosion of work in this area, it draws on  a relatively narrow set of disciplines for inspiration, largely economics and behavioral psychology.  In this project, we aimed to expand the inspiration for software design in this area by analyzing how eco-artists use new technologies to address issues around environmental sustainability. 

Our prior work in this area suggested that a major potential avenue for inspiration would be the way eco-artists work with public participation and engagement. While sustainable software design tends to focus on a one-way educational mission, in which software is intended to educate consumers about how to be more sustainable, eco-artists emphasize a participatory, democratic approach in which artists work with and support local communities and organizations in defining and taking action on environmental issues that make sense to them. In this project, we planned to examine the tactics that eco-artists use to engage with publics and how they leverage new technologies in order to do so, as an inspiration for new forms of software design.

To answer these questions, we engaged in social science research at a prominent festival for eco-artists using participatory methods, the SJ01 Biennial.  We interviewed artists, organizers, and audience members, analyzed the artworks on display, participated in artists' talks and workshops, and collected fieldnotes from our collaborators at Georgia Tech, who were themselves displaying artwork at the festival. After analyzing this data, we engaged in follow-on interviews with artists asking them to reflect on their experiences at the festival.

While our initial goal was to examine how eco-artists achieve participation on the ground,  what we found in the fieldwork was substantially different. Despite the strong emphasis on public participation and the fostering of dialogue in artists' statements, there seemed to be little meaningful participation and dialogue on the ground.  We documented many instances of befuddled audiences and of artists and audiences speaking past each other, and few instances of true communication. What went wrong?

Our subsequent analysis of the data revealed many aspects by which the organization and institutionalization of arts practices undermines their stated goal.  In other words, while artists care about public participation, they are not remunerated for it.  Similarly, audience members' cultural frames towards what it means to consumer art do not necessarily lead them to want to engage in deep discussions with artists and their representatives; harried visitors may prefer immediate experience of something 'cool'.. Successful artists are those who can accrue 'buzz' in the media, among curators, and among other artists, not those who most successfully and deeply communicate concepts and methods with exhibit visitors. The concept of participation is rewarded in contemporary arts practice, not its actual execution. 

In reflecting on this situation, we realized that in many ways sustainable software development is in a similar state.  Researchers exploring how to design for sustainabiltiy are not rewarded for actually improving sustainability; they are rewarded for big ideas and for conference and journal papers which yield measurable scientific results. We therefore have used the results of our fieldwork in large part as a stimulus for rethinking the institutional pressures on sustainable software development researchers and how they may lead to both more and less sustainability, regardless of the intentions of researchers.  At the same time, we are using opportunities and strategies we have identified that did lead to more participation in eco-arts venues as inspiration for te...
